elements.content: Lithium 4,5-dicyano-1,2,3-triazolate (LiDCTA) and lithium 2-trifluoromethyl-4,5-dicyanoimidazole (LiTDI) are two salts proposed for lithium battery electrolyte applications, but little is known about the manner in which the DCTA– and TDI– anions coordinate Li+ cations. To explore this in depth, crystal structures are reported here for two solvates with LiDCTA(G2)1:LiDCTA and (G1)1:LiDCTAwith diglyme and monoglyme, respectively; and seven solvates with LiTDI(G1)2:LiTDI, (G2)2:LiTDI, (G3)1:LiTDI, (THF)1:LiTDI, (EC)1:LiTDI, (PC)1:LiTDI, and (DMC)1/2:LiTDIwith monoglyme, diglyme, triglyme, tetrahydrofuran, ethylene carbonate, propylene carbonate, and dimethyl carbonate, respectively. These latter solvate structures are compared with the previously reported acetonitrile (AN)2:LiTDI structure. The solvates indicate that the LiTDI salt is much less associated than the LiDCTA salt and that the ions in LiTDI, when aggregated in solvates, have a very similar TDI–···Li+ cation mode of coordination through both the anion ring and cyano nitrogen atoms. Such coordination facilitates the formation of polymeric ion aggregates, instead of dimers. Insight into such ion speciation is instrumental for understanding the electrolyte properties of aprotic solvent mixtures with these salts.
elements.clean_text: Lithium 4,5-dicyano-1,2,3-triazolate (LiDCTA) and lithium 2-trifluoromethyl-4,5-dicyanoimidazole (LiTDI) are two salts proposed for lithium battery electrolyte applications, but little is known about the manner in which the DCTA- and TDI- anions coordinate Li+ cations. To explore this in depth, crystal structures are reported here for two solvates with LiDCTA(G2)1:LiDCTA and (G1)1:LiDCTAwith diglyme and monoglyme, respectively; and seven solvates with LiTDI(G1)2:LiTDI, (G2)2:LiTDI, (G3)1:LiTDI, (THF)1:LiTDI, (EC)1:LiTDI, (PC)1:LiTDI, and (DMC)1/2:LiTDIwith monoglyme, diglyme, triglyme, tetrahydrofuran, ethylene carbonate, propylene carbonate, and dimethyl carbonate, respectively. These latter solvate structures are compared with the previously reported acetonitrile (AN)2:LiTDI structure. The solvates indicate that the LiTDI salt is much less associated than the LiDCTA salt and that the ions in LiTDI, when aggregated in solvates, have a very similar TDI-⋅⋅⋅Li+ cation mode of coordination through both the anion ring and cyano nitrogen atoms. Such coordination facilitates the formation of polymeric ion aggregates, instead of dimers. Insight into such ion speciation is instrumental for understanding the electrolyte properties of aprotic solvent mixtures with these salts.

elements.content: Electrolyte interactions largely govern lithium battery performance (power, cycle life, and safety characteristics), but such interactions remain poorly understood. As lithium cell chemistries for advanced batteries have rapidly progressed with new cathodes (high-voltage metal oxides, sulfur, air, etc.) and anodes (Li metal, Li–Si alloy, etc.), it has become evident that the state-of-the-art salt LiPF6which has been predominantly used in commercial Li-ion battery electrolytes for more than a quarter of a centurymay no longer be optimal. LiPF6 has long been the salt of choice, as electrolytes with this salt have some of the highest ionic conductivity values measured for aprotic solvent-based electrolytes. Such electrolytes also react to form both a stable interface with Al metal at high potentials (the current collector used for cathodes) and a favorable solid–electrolyte interface (SEI) with graphite anodes when carbonate solvents are used. However, the PF6 – anion also contains labile P–F bonds which result in the salt readily undergoing hydrolysis and having a relatively low thermal stability. The HF, common to LiPF6-based electrolytes, from such instability is known to have a deleterious impact on cell performance, especially at elevated temperature. New electrolyte salts have therefore been avidly sought, but identifying promising anions which meet the myriad property requirements for lithium battery electrolytes has been quite challenging. In recent years, lithium salts having two structurally similar anions have been proposed for battery electrolytes: 4,5-dicyano-1,2,3-triazolate (DCTA–)also known as 1,2,3-triazole-4,5-dicarbonitrile (TADC–)and 2-trifluoro-4,5-dicyanoimidazolide (TDI–):Despite their structural similarities, lithium salts with these anions are found to result in remarkably different electrolyte properties.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Electrolyte interactions largely govern lithium battery performance (power, cycle life, and safety characteristics), but such interactions remain poorly understood. As lithium cell chemistries for advanced batteries have rapidly progressed with new cathodes (high-voltage metal oxides, sulfur, air, etc.) and anodes (Li metal, Li-Si alloy, etc.), it has become evident that the state-of-the-art salt LiPF6which has been predominantly used in commercial Li-ion battery electrolytes for more than a quarter of a centurymay no longer be optimal. LiPF6 has long been the salt of choice, as electrolytes with this salt have some of the highest ionic conductivity values measured for aprotic solvent-based electrolytes. Such electrolytes also react to form both a stable interface with Al metal at high potentials (the current collector used for cathodes) and a favorable solid-electrolyte interface (SEI) with graphite anodes when carbonate solvents are used. However, the PF6 - anion also contains labile P-F bonds which result in the salt readily undergoing hydrolysis and having a relatively low thermal stability. The HF, common to LiPF6-based electrolytes, from such instability is known to have a deleterious impact on cell performance, especially at elevated temperature. New electrolyte salts have therefore been avidly sought, but identifying promising anions which meet the myriad property requirements for lithium battery electrolytes has been quite challenging. In recent years, lithium salts having two structurally similar anions have been proposed for battery electrolytes: 4,5-dicyano-1,2,3-triazolate (DCTA-)also known as 1,2,3-triazole-4,5-dicarbonitrile (TADC-)and 2-trifluoro-4,5-dicyanoimidazolide (TDI-):Despite their structural similarities, lithium salts with these anions are found to result in remarkably different electrolyte properties.

elements.content: LiDCTA was first prepared by Michot in 1995 and reported in two publications in 2003. Although LiDCTA was found to be highly soluble in polyethylene oxide (PEO), the ionic conductivity of the resulting polymer electrolytes was found to be relatively low. The electrolyte consisting of 1 M LiDCTA in propylene carbonate (PC) is also much less conductive than the corresponding electrolyte with LiPF6. When paired with organic cations, the DCTA– anion readily forms low melting salts (i.e., ionic liquids) with a low viscosity, perhaps suggesting that this anion may be weakly coordinating due to the extensive negative charge delocalization across the anion’s structure. The relatively low conductivity of electrolytes with LiDCTA, however, contradicts this notion. In addition, the 1 M PC-LiDCTA electrolyte is highly reactive with an Al electrode at <4.0 V (vs Li/Li+) indicating that the DCTA– anion is unable to passivate the Al current collector to prevent corrosion.
elements.clean_text: LiDCTA was first prepared by Michot in 1995 and reported in two publications in 2003. Although LiDCTA was found to be highly soluble in polyethylene oxide (PEO), the ionic conductivity of the resulting polymer electrolytes was found to be relatively low. The electrolyte consisting of 1 M LiDCTA in propylene carbonate (PC) is also much less conductive than the corresponding electrolyte with LiPF6. When paired with organic cations, the DCTA- anion readily forms low melting salts (i.e., ionic liquids) with a low viscosity, perhaps suggesting that this anion may be weakly coordinating due to the extensive negative charge delocalization across the anion's structure. The relatively low conductivity of electrolytes with LiDCTA, however, contradicts this notion. In addition, the 1 M PC-LiDCTA electrolyte is highly reactive with an Al electrode at <4.0 V (vs Li/Li+) indicating that the DCTA- anion is unable to passivate the Al current collector to prevent corrosion.

elements.content: LiTDI was first reported by Bukowska et al. in 2004. Only a few publications are, as yet, available exploring the properties of this salt. In contrast with many other lithium salts (e.g., LiPF6), LiTDI is stable in water. In terms of electrolyte properties, 1 M LiTDI in ethylene carbonate/dimethyl carbonate (EC/DMC 50/50 w/w) has a conductivity of 6.7 mS cm–1 at 20 °C (the value for the corresponding LiPF6 electrolyte is 10.8 mS cm–1) and cycles well in Li|LiMn2O4 cells (comparable to cells with a similar electrolyte with LiPF6 up to a 2C rate). In addition, this LiTDI electrolyte is electrochemically stable with an Al electrode up to 4.8 V. Thus, LiTDI, in contrast with the structurally similar LiDCTA salt, holds promise as a practical electrolyte salt for batteries with high-voltage cathode materials.
elements.clean_text: LiTDI was first reported by Bukowska et al. in 2004. Only a few publications are, as yet, available exploring the properties of this salt. In contrast with many other lithium salts (e.g., LiPF6), LiTDI is stable in water. In terms of electrolyte properties, 1 M LiTDI in ethylene carbonate/dimethyl carbonate (EC/DMC 50/50 w/w) has a conductivity of 6.7 mS cm-1 at 20 °C (the value for the corresponding LiPF6 electrolyte is 10.8 mS cm-1) and cycles well in Li|LiMn2O4 cells (comparable to cells with a similar electrolyte with LiPF6 up to a 2C rate). In addition, this LiTDI electrolyte is electrochemically stable with an Al electrode up to 4.8 V. Thus, LiTDI, in contrast with the structurally similar LiDCTA salt, holds promise as a practical electrolyte salt for batteries with high-voltage cathode materials.

elements.content: While computational studies have been used to predict the ion interactions within electrolytes to explain properties, only limited experimental information is available regarding the specific manner in which the DCTA– and TDI– anions interacts with Li+ cations. Knowledge of the ion and solvent coordination interactions which are possible, however, provides a key foundation for explaining/predicting the observed macroscale physicochemical properties of electrolytes and, in turn, the performance of the batteries employing such electrolytes. Solvate crystal structures impart such insight, which is unavailable from other experimental methods. Crystal structures for solvates with both LiDCTA and LiTDI are therefore reported here to aid in understanding the molecular-level properties of electrolytes with these salts.
elements.clean_text: While computational studies have been used to predict the ion interactions within electrolytes to explain properties, only limited experimental information is available regarding the specific manner in which the DCTA- and TDI- anions interacts with Li+ cations. Knowledge of the ion and solvent coordination interactions which are possible, however, provides a key foundation for explaining/predicting the observed macroscale physicochemical properties of electrolytes and, in turn, the performance of the batteries employing such electrolytes. Solvate crystal structures impart such insight, which is unavailable from other experimental methods. Crystal structures for solvates with both LiDCTA and LiTDI are therefore reported here to aid in understanding the molecular-level properties of electrolytes with these salts.

elements.content: The materials used for the salt preparation: diaminomaleonitrile (Fisher Scientific, 98%), tert-butyl nitrite (Sigma Aldrich, 90%), trifluoroacetic anhydride (Fisher Scientific, > 99%), lithium carbonate (Li2CO3, Fisher Scientific, > 99%), activated carbon (Fisher Scientific), activated alumina (Fisher Scientific), diethyl ether (Et2O, Fisher Scientific, > 99.0%), dichloromethane (CH2Cl2, Sigma Aldrich, > 99.9%), n-pentane (Sigma Aldrich, > 99%), and ethanol (EtOH, Fisher Scientific, denatured, reagent grade) were used as-received.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental and Computational Methods

Materials

The materials used for the salt preparation: diaminomaleonitrile (Fisher Scientific, 98%), tert-butyl nitrite (Sigma Aldrich, 90%), trifluoroacetic anhydride (Fisher Scientific, > 99%), lithium carbonate (Li2CO3, Fisher Scientific, > 99%), activated carbon (Fisher Scientific), activated alumina (Fisher Scientific), diethyl ether (Et2O, Fisher Scientific, > 99.0%), dichloromethane (CH2Cl2, Sigma Aldrich, > 99.9%), n-pentane (Sigma Aldrich, > 99%), and ethanol (EtOH, Fisher Scientific, denatured, reagent grade) were used as-received.

elements.content: The solvents used for solvate crystallization (Chart )acetonitrile (AN, Sigma Aldrich, 99.9%), dimethyl carbonate (DMC, Sigma Aldrich, > 99%), propylene carbonate (PC, Novolyte, > 99%), 1,2-dimethoxyethane (monoglyme or G1, Sigma Aldrich, anhydrous 99.5%), diethylene glycol dimethyl ether (diglyme or G2, Sigma Aldrich, anhydrous 99.5%), and triethylene glycol dimethyl ether (triglyme or G3, Sigma Aldrich, 99%)were stored over 3 Å molecular sieves prior to use. Tetrahydrofuran (THF, Fisher Scientific, > 99.9%) was distilled over Na metal with benzophenone indicator. Ethylene carbonate (EC, Novolyte, electrolyte-grade 99.9%) was used as received. These solvents were confirmed to be anhydrous (<20 ppm H2O), as determined with a Mettler Toledo DL39 Karl Fischer coulometer. All of the materials (except for the Et2O, ethanol, and lithium carbonate) were stored in a N2 glovebox (<5 ppm O2 and <1 ppm H2O).
elements.clean_text: The solvents used for solvate crystallization (Chart )acetonitrile (AN, Sigma Aldrich, 99.9%), dimethyl carbonate (DMC, Sigma Aldrich, > 99%), propylene carbonate (PC, Novolyte, > 99%), 1,2-dimethoxyethane (monoglyme or G1, Sigma Aldrich, anhydrous 99.5%), diethylene glycol dimethyl ether (diglyme or G2, Sigma Aldrich, anhydrous 99.5%), and triethylene glycol dimethyl ether (triglyme or G3, Sigma Aldrich, 99%)were stored over 3 Å molecular sieves prior to use. Tetrahydrofuran (THF, Fisher Scientific, > 99.9%) was distilled over Na metal with benzophenone indicator. Ethylene carbonate (EC, Novolyte, electrolyte-grade 99.9%) was used as received. These solvents were confirmed to be anhydrous (<20 ppm H2O), as determined with a Mettler Toledo DL39 Karl Fischer coulometer. All of the materials (except for the Et2O, ethanol, and lithium carbonate) were stored in a N2 glovebox (<5 ppm O2 and <1 ppm H2O).

elements.clean_text: 1  Structures and Acronyms of the Solvents Used

elements.content: LiDCTA was synthesized in a two-step procedure by methods described previously. First, HDCTA was synthesized by dissolving diaminomaleonitrile in Et2O (cooled in an ice bath). After 30 min, tert-butyl nitrite was added. The solution was stirred for 8 h and then stored at 4 °C for another 48 h. The resulting solution, which contained dark solid particles, was centrifuged to separate the liquid phase. The liquid was then evaporated at 50 °C resulting in crude HDCTA (brownish/reddish powder with white crystals). The crude HDCTA was then sublimated repeatedly until pure white crystals were obtained. Purified HDCTA was then reacted with a 10% excess of Li2CO3 in anhydrous AN to form LiDCTA. The AN solution was filtered to remove solids and the AN was then evaporated leaving LiDCTA in the form of a white powder. The LiDCTA was then vacuum-dried at 80 °C for 48 h before storing the sample in a hermetically-sealed bottle in the glovebox.
elements.clean_text:
Salt Preparation

LiDCTA was synthesized in a two-step procedure by methods described previously. First, HDCTA was synthesized by dissolving diaminomaleonitrile in Et2O (cooled in an ice bath). After 30 min, tert-butyl nitrite was added. The solution was stirred for 8 h and then stored at 4 °C for another 48 h. The resulting solution, which contained dark solid particles, was centrifuged to separate the liquid phase. The liquid was then evaporated at 50 °C resulting in crude HDCTA (brownish/reddish powder with white crystals). The crude HDCTA was then sublimated repeatedly until pure white crystals were obtained. Purified HDCTA was then reacted with a 10% excess of Li2CO3 in anhydrous AN to form LiDCTA. The AN solution was filtered to remove solids and the AN was then evaporated leaving LiDCTA in the form of a white powder. The LiDCTA was then vacuum-dried at 80 °C for 48 h before storing the sample in a hermetically-sealed bottle in the glovebox.

elements.content: LiTDI was synthesized by methods described in the literature, with THF used instead of 1,4-dioxane. The crude HTDI acid was reacted with a 20% excess of Li2CO3 in EtOH, treated with activated carbon overnight at 60 °C, and dried in a rotary evaporator to yield a yellow solid. Washing with Et2O followed by filtration resulted in a white solid. This LiTDI salt was twice recrystallized in AN (forming the (AN)2:LiTDI crystalline solvate) before treatment with activated alumina in anhydrous AN to remove residual H2O. The purified salt was then vacuum-dried at 110 °C for 24 h before storing the sample in a hermetically sealed bottle in the glovebox.
elements.clean_text: LiTDI was synthesized by methods described in the literature, with THF used instead of 1,4-dioxane. The crude HTDI acid was reacted with a 20% excess of Li2CO3 in EtOH, treated with activated carbon overnight at 60 °C, and dried in a rotary evaporator to yield a yellow solid. Washing with Et2O followed by filtration resulted in a white solid. This LiTDI salt was twice recrystallized in AN (forming the (AN)2:LiTDI crystalline solvate) before treatment with activated alumina in anhydrous AN to remove residual H2O. The purified salt was then vacuum-dried at 110 °C for 24 h before storing the sample in a hermetically sealed bottle in the glovebox.

elements.content: In general, the solvate single crystals were formed by slowly cooling hot, saturated solutions of the LiDCTA or LiTDI salts in the solvents. In some cases, vapor diffusion of a volatile, nonpolar solvent (i.e., n-pentane or CH2Cl2) into the solution of interest was used instead to initiate crystallization of single crystals (see ). Single crystals were typically mounted on nylon loops with a small amount of Paratone-N oil. X-ray measurements were made on a Bruker-Nonius Kappa Axis X8 Apex2 diffractometer. The unit cell dimensions were determined from symmetry constrained fits of the reflections. The frame integrations were performed using SAINT. The resulting raw data were scaled and absorption corrected using a multiscan averaging of symmetry equivalent data using SADABS. The structures were solved by direct methods using the SIR92 or XS programs. All non-hydrogen atoms were obtained from the initial solution. The hydrogen atoms were introduced at idealized positions and allowed to ride on the parent atom. The structural models were fit to the data using full matrix least-squares based on F 2. The calculated structure factors included corrections for anomalous dispersion from the usual tabulation. The structures were refined using the XL program from SHELXTL (). Structures were drawn using Mercury 3.0. Crystallographic information data files (CIFs) for HDCTA, HTDI, and the LiDCTA/LiTDI solvates are available in the and free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif: CCDC 957353–957359, 971639, and 977446–977449. Mercury freeware software to view the content of these files is also available: www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/free_services/mercury/downloads/.
elements.clean_text:
Solvate Crystal Structure Determination

In general, the solvate single crystals were formed by slowly cooling hot, saturated solutions of the LiDCTA or LiTDI salts in the solvents. In some cases, vapor diffusion of a volatile, nonpolar solvent (i.e., n-pentane or CH2Cl2) into the solution of interest was used instead to initiate crystallization of single crystals (see ). Single crystals were typically mounted on nylon loops with a small amount of Paratone-N oil. X-ray measurements were made on a Bruker-Nonius Kappa Axis X8 Apex2 diffractometer. The unit cell dimensions were determined from symmetry constrained fits of the reflections. The frame integrations were performed using SAINT. The resulting raw data were scaled and absorption corrected using a multiscan averaging of symmetry equivalent data using SADABS. The structures were solved by direct methods using the SIR92 or XS programs. All non-hydrogen atoms were obtained from the initial solution. The hydrogen atoms were introduced at idealized positions and allowed to ride on the parent atom. The structural models were fit to the data using full matrix least-squares based on F 2. The calculated structure factors included corrections for anomalous dispersion from the usual tabulation. The structures were refined using the XL program from SHELXTL (). Structures were drawn using Mercury 3.0. Crystallographic information data files (CIFs) for HDCTA, HTDI, and the LiDCTA/LiTDI solvates are available in the  and free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif: CCDC 957353-957359, 971639, and 977446-977449. Mercury freeware software to view the content of these files is also available: www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/free_services/mercury/downloads/.

elements.content: The DCTA– anion has five possible donor atoms for cation coordination, including three ring and two cyano nitrogen atoms. The numerous resonance structures for the DCTA– anion indicate that the negative charge can be delocalized on all five nitrogen atoms. The HDCTA acid crystal structure has been previously reported, but this was also determined as part of the present investigationsee (the crystal structure of LiDCTA is also known). In this structure (Figure a), each DCTA– anion is coordinated to three protons (H+ cations) using two ring and one cyano nitrogen atoms. Each proton is therefore coordinated by three nitrogen atoms from three anions.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

HDCTA and HTDI Acid Crystal Structures

The DCTA- anion has five possible donor atoms for cation coordination, including three ring and two cyano nitrogen atoms. The numerous resonance structures for the DCTA- anion indicate that the negative charge can be delocalized on all five nitrogen atoms. The HDCTA acid crystal structure has been previously reported, but this was also determined as part of the present investigationsee  (the crystal structure of LiDCTA is also known). In this structure (Figure a), each DCTA- anion is coordinated to three protons (H+ cations) using two ring and one cyano nitrogen atoms. Each proton is therefore coordinated by three nitrogen atoms from three anions.

elements.content: Ion coordination in the (a) HDCTA and (b) HTDI acid crystal structures with hydrogen bonding between adjacent molecules shown (dashed lines) (N-blue, F-light green).
elements.clean_text: 1  Ion coordination in the (a) HDCTA and (b) HTDI acid crystal structures with hydrogen bonding between adjacent molecules shown (dashed lines) (N-blue, F-light green).

elements.content: The TDI– anion has four possible donor atoms for cation coordination, including two ring and two cyano nitrogen atoms. The solvates reported herein indicate that the anion fluorine atoms do not participate in cation coordination, as is typical for anion fluorine atoms bonded to carbon atoms. In the HTDI acid crystal structure, each TDI– anion is coordinated to two protons using one ring and one cyano nitrogen atom. The TDI– ring nitrogen atoms shown as uncoordinated (to protons) in Figure b are actually located near another neighboring proton (not shown) and thus may be considered to be very weakly coordinated to a third proton. Each proton is therefore coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two anions with a third nitrogen atom (from a third anion) located in close proximity.
elements.clean_text: The TDI- anion has four possible donor atoms for cation coordination, including two ring and two cyano nitrogen atoms. The solvates reported herein indicate that the anion fluorine atoms do not participate in cation coordination, as is typical for anion fluorine atoms bonded to carbon atoms. In the HTDI acid crystal structure, each TDI- anion is coordinated to two protons using one ring and one cyano nitrogen atom. The TDI- ring nitrogen atoms shown as uncoordinated (to protons) in Figure b are actually located near another neighboring proton (not shown) and thus may be considered to be very weakly coordinated to a third proton. Each proton is therefore coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two anions with a third nitrogen atom (from a third anion) located in close proximity.

elements.content: Tremendous differences are noted in electrolyte properties when different lithium salts (i.e., anions) are utilized due to strong variations in solvation (solvent···Li+ cation) and ionic association (anion···Li+ cation) interactions. For lithium battery electrolytes, which are based upon aprotic solvents, the anions have only weak coordination with the solvent molecules. This is evident in the crystalline solvates reported below. A competition therefore exists between the anions and solvent molecules for coordination to the Li+ cations within the cation coordination shells. The resulting ionic association interactions are frequently classified using solvent-separated ion pair (SSIP), contact ion pair (CIP), and aggregate (AGG) terminology for the solvates. In reality, however, this classification is too simplistic. Since spectroscopic methods are generally used to identify ionic association interactions via the anion vibrational bands, this classification is based upon the anion (rather than Li+ cation) interactions. With this in mind, the CIP coordination can be further distinguished as CIP-I, CIP-II, or CIP-III if the anions are coordinated to a single Li+ cation using one, two, or three donor atoms, respectively. The AGG coordination can then be designated as AGG-I, AGG-II, or AGG-III if the anions are coordinated to two, three, or four or more Li+ cations, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Lithium Salt Crystalline Solvates and Ionic Association

Tremendous differences are noted in electrolyte properties when different lithium salts (i.e., anions) are utilized due to strong variations in solvation (solvent⋅⋅⋅Li+ cation) and ionic association (anion⋅⋅⋅Li+ cation) interactions. For lithium battery electrolytes, which are based upon aprotic solvents, the anions have only weak coordination with the solvent molecules. This is evident in the crystalline solvates reported below. A competition therefore exists between the anions and solvent molecules for coordination to the Li+ cations within the cation coordination shells. The resulting ionic association interactions are frequently classified using solvent-separated ion pair (SSIP), contact ion pair (CIP), and aggregate (AGG) terminology for the solvates. In reality, however, this classification is too simplistic. Since spectroscopic methods are generally used to identify ionic association interactions via the anion vibrational bands, this classification is based upon the anion (rather than Li+ cation) interactions. With this in mind, the CIP coordination can be further distinguished as CIP-I, CIP-II, or CIP-III if the anions are coordinated to a single Li+ cation using one, two, or three donor atoms, respectively. The AGG coordination can then be designated as AGG-I, AGG-II, or AGG-III if the anions are coordinated to two, three, or four or more Li+ cations, respectively.

elements.content: As noted above, aprotic solvent-based electrolytes with LiDCTA tend to have a low conductivity, as compared to similar electrolytes with LiPF6. This suggests that instead of the ions being fully dissociated (i.e., the Li+ cations being fully solvated) extensive ionic association (anion···Li+ cation coordination) is present in such electrolytes. It has previously been demonstrated that the ionic association tendency of lithium salts can be gauged by scrutinizing which crystalline solvates form from glyme-LiX mixtures. For example, (G1) n -LiX mixtures are able to form SSIP (G1)3:LiX, CIP (G1)2:LiX, and AGG-I (G1)1:LiX crystalline solvates in which the anions are coordinated to zero, one, or two Li+ cations, respectively. Similarly, (G2) n -LiX mixtures tend to form SSIP (G2)2:LiX and AGG-I (G2)1:LiX crystalline solvates, whereas (G3) n -LiX mixtures tend to form SSIP (G3)2:LiX and CIP (G3)1:LiX crystalline solvates. Salts with a weak ionic association tendency (e.g., LiAsF6) generally form crystalline phases with anions uncoordinated to Li+ cations (i.e., (G1)3:LiX, (G2)2:LiX, and (G3)2:LiX), while salts which are much more associated (e.g., LiCF3SO3 and LiCF3CO2) either form these same phases with a much lower melting point (T m) or instead form the more associated phases from dilute solutions.
elements.clean_text:
Glyme-LiDCTA and -LiTDI Crystalline Solvate Structures

As noted above, aprotic solvent-based electrolytes with LiDCTA tend to have a low conductivity, as compared to similar electrolytes with LiPF6. This suggests that instead of the ions being fully dissociated (i.e., the Li+ cations being fully solvated) extensive ionic association (anion⋅⋅⋅Li+ cation coordination) is present in such electrolytes. It has previously been demonstrated that the ionic association tendency of lithium salts can be gauged by scrutinizing which crystalline solvates form from glyme-LiX mixtures. For example, (G1) n -LiX mixtures are able to form SSIP (G1)3:LiX, CIP (G1)2:LiX, and AGG-I (G1)1:LiX crystalline solvates in which the anions are coordinated to zero, one, or two Li+ cations, respectively. Similarly, (G2) n -LiX mixtures tend to form SSIP (G2)2:LiX and AGG-I (G2)1:LiX crystalline solvates, whereas (G3) n -LiX mixtures tend to form SSIP (G3)2:LiX and CIP (G3)1:LiX crystalline solvates. Salts with a weak ionic association tendency (e.g., LiAsF6) generally form crystalline phases with anions uncoordinated to Li+ cations (i.e., (G1)3:LiX, (G2)2:LiX, and (G3)2:LiX), while salts which are much more associated (e.g., LiCF3SO3 and LiCF3CO2) either form these same phases with a much lower melting point (T m) or instead form the more associated phases from dilute solutions.

elements.content: Utilizing this methodology to explore the ionic association tendency of the salts, crystalline solvates with LiDCTA or LiTDI were grown from G1 and G2 solutions. The LiDCTA solutions with excess solvent did not result in SSIP (G1)3:LiDCTA or SSIP (G2)2:LiDCTA crystalline solvate phases with DCTA– anions uncoordinated to Li+ cations, nor was a CIP (G1)2:LiDCTA phase formed. Instead, the obtained crystals consist of AGG-I (G1)1:LiDCTA and AGG-I (G2)1:LiDCTA solvate phases in which the DCTA– anions are cooordinated to two Li+ cations using two of the ring nitrogen atoms (Figure a and b). Each cation, in turn, is coordinated to two anions thereby creating similar dimers of two ion pairs.
elements.clean_text: Utilizing this methodology to explore the ionic association tendency of the salts, crystalline solvates with LiDCTA or LiTDI were grown from G1 and G2 solutions. The LiDCTA solutions with excess solvent did not result in SSIP (G1)3:LiDCTA or SSIP (G2)2:LiDCTA crystalline solvate phases with DCTA- anions uncoordinated to Li+ cations, nor was a CIP (G1)2:LiDCTA phase formed. Instead, the obtained crystals consist of AGG-I (G1)1:LiDCTA and AGG-I (G2)1:LiDCTA solvate phases in which the DCTA- anions are cooordinated to two Li+ cations using two of the ring nitrogen atoms (Figure a and b). Each cation, in turn, is coordinated to two anions thereby creating similar dimers of two ion pairs.

elements.content: Ion coordination in the (a) AGG-I (G1)1:LiDCTA and (b) AGG-I (G2)1:LiDCTA solvate crystal structures (Li-purple, O-red, N-blue).
elements.clean_text: 2  Ion coordination in the (a) AGG-I (G1)1:LiDCTA and (b) AGG-I (G2)1:LiDCTA solvate crystal structures (Li-purple, O-red, N-blue).

elements.content: The glyme mixtures with LiTDI, however, have a quite different phase behavior (Figure ). A (G1) n -LiTDI (n = 2) mixture forms a (G1)2:LiTDI crystalline phase which melts at 19 °C. The ion coordination within this phase is shown in Figure a. Each anion is coordinated to a single Li+ cation using one of the ring nitrogen atoms. Each Li+ cation has fivefold coordination to a single TDI– anion and four oxygen atoms from two G1 molecules. A (G1) n -LiTDI (n = 3) mixture displays a DSC endothermic peak near 6 °C which is attributed to this phase (the temperature is lowered relative to the n = 2 sample due to the liquidus curve). Additional peaks at −66 and −36 °C are due to crystalline G1 and another crystalline phase which is likely a SSIP (G1)3:LiTDI phase, as is found with many other lithium salts. Note that it was not possible to fully crystallize the sample into this phase. Instead, depending upon the thermal history of the sample, some amount of the CIP-I (G1)2:LiTDI phase always crystallized (which resulted in excess G1 when the remainder of the sample crystallized as the SSIP (G1)3:LiTDI phase)this variation in the phase behavior is shown in Figure for two different sample pans prepared from the same (G1) n -LiTDI (n = 3) mixture. Note that the DSC peaks near 120 °C for these samples are due to the rupture of the hermetically-sealed DSC pan due to the pressure from the vaporized G1 solvent.
elements.clean_text: The glyme mixtures with LiTDI, however, have a quite different phase behavior (Figure ). A (G1) n -LiTDI (n = 2) mixture forms a (G1)2:LiTDI crystalline phase which melts at 19 °C. The ion coordination within this phase is shown in Figure a. Each anion is coordinated to a single Li+ cation using one of the ring nitrogen atoms. Each Li+ cation has fivefold coordination to a single TDI- anion and four oxygen atoms from two G1 molecules. A (G1) n -LiTDI (n = 3) mixture displays a DSC endothermic peak near 6 °C which is attributed to this phase (the temperature is lowered relative to the n = 2 sample due to the liquidus curve). Additional peaks at -66 and -36 °C are due to crystalline G1 and another crystalline phase which is likely a SSIP (G1)3:LiTDI phase, as is found with many other lithium salts. Note that it was not possible to fully crystallize the sample into this phase. Instead, depending upon the thermal history of the sample, some amount of the CIP-I (G1)2:LiTDI phase always crystallized (which resulted in excess G1 when the remainder of the sample crystallized as the SSIP (G1)3:LiTDI phase)this variation in the phase behavior is shown in Figure  for two different sample pans prepared from the same (G1) n -LiTDI (n = 3) mixture. Note that the DSC peaks near 120 °C for these samples are due to the rupture of the hermetically-sealed DSC pan due to the pressure from the vaporized G1 solvent.

elements.content: DSC heating traces (5 °C min–1) of glyme and (glyme) n -LiTDI mixtures.
elements.clean_text: 3  DSC heating traces (5 °C min-1) of glyme and (glyme) n -LiTDI mixtures.

elements.content: Ion coordination in the (a) CIP-I (G1)2:LiTDI, (b) SSIP (G2)2:LiTDI, and (c) CIP-I (G3)1:LiTDI solvate crystal structures (Li-purple, O-red, N-blue, F-light green).
elements.clean_text: 4  Ion coordination in the (a) CIP-I (G1)2:LiTDI, (b) SSIP (G2)2:LiTDI, and (c) CIP-I (G3)1:LiTDI solvate crystal structures (Li-purple, O-red, N-blue, F-light green).

elements.content: The (G2) n -LiTDI (n = 2) mixture forms a (G2)2:LiTDI crystalline phase which melts at 104 °C. A common motif in (G2)2:LiX solvates, which is present in the SSIP (G2)2:LiTDI crystalline solvate (Figure b), is for two G2 molecules to coordinate the Li+ cations, thereby shielding them from the anions. Thus, the Li+ cations are sixfold coordinated by six oxygen atoms, and the TDI– anions are uncoordinated to the Li+ cations.
elements.clean_text: The (G2) n -LiTDI (n = 2) mixture forms a (G2)2:LiTDI crystalline phase which melts at 104 °C. A common motif in (G2)2:LiX solvates, which is present in the SSIP (G2)2:LiTDI crystalline solvate (Figure b), is for two G2 molecules to coordinate the Li+ cations, thereby shielding them from the anions. Thus, the Li+ cations are sixfold coordinated by six oxygen atoms, and the TDI- anions are uncoordinated to the Li+ cations.

elements.content: The (G3) n -LiTDI (n = 1) mixture forms a (G3)1:LiTDI crystalline phase which melts at 48 °C. The n = 1.5 mixture has a broad peak at a slightly lower temperature (34 °C) due to the liquidus curve and, instead of an endothermic peak for the excess G3 or a SSIP (G3)2:LiTDI phase, a glass transition (T g) is noted at −95 °C indicating that the remainder of the sample did not crystallize. The CIP-I (G3)1:LiTDI crystalline solvate phase resembles the coordination found for the (G3)1:LiBETI (i.e., LiN(SO2C2F5)2) solvate. The Li+ cations are fivefold coordinated by one TDI– anion through one ring nitrogen atom and four oxygen atoms from a single G3 molecule (Figure c). The cation coordination therefore also closely resembles that of the CIP-I (G1)2:LiTDI solvate (Figure a). In these two solvates, the solvated ion pairs are isolated from one another. CIP (G3)1:LiX crystalline solvates with smaller anions (i.e., LiBF4, LiClO4, LiCF3SO3, and LiAsF6), however, have a linear polymer structure in which the G3 molecules coordinates two Li+ cations using two oxygen atoms for each. Each Li+ cation is therefore fivefold coordinated to four oxygen atoms from two G3 molecules and a single donor atom from an anion. The larger size of the TDI– (or BETI–) anion, however, precludes this form of ion and solvent coordination/packing, thus resulting in the coordination of the G3 molecules to a single Li+ cation.
elements.clean_text: The (G3) n -LiTDI (n = 1) mixture forms a (G3)1:LiTDI crystalline phase which melts at 48 °C. The n = 1.5 mixture has a broad peak at a slightly lower temperature (34 °C) due to the liquidus curve and, instead of an endothermic peak for the excess G3 or a SSIP (G3)2:LiTDI phase, a glass transition (T g) is noted at -95 °C indicating that the remainder of the sample did not crystallize. The CIP-I (G3)1:LiTDI crystalline solvate phase resembles the coordination found for the (G3)1:LiBETI (i.e., LiN(SO2C2F5)2) solvate. The Li+ cations are fivefold coordinated by one TDI- anion through one ring nitrogen atom and four oxygen atoms from a single G3 molecule (Figure c). The cation coordination therefore also closely resembles that of the CIP-I (G1)2:LiTDI solvate (Figure a). In these two solvates, the solvated ion pairs are isolated from one another. CIP (G3)1:LiX crystalline solvates with smaller anions (i.e., LiBF4, LiClO4, LiCF3SO3, and LiAsF6), however, have a linear polymer structure in which the G3 molecules coordinates two Li+ cations using two oxygen atoms for each. Each Li+ cation is therefore fivefold coordinated to four oxygen atoms from two G3 molecules and a single donor atom from an anion. The larger size of the TDI- (or BETI-) anion, however, precludes this form of ion and solvent coordination/packing, thus resulting in the coordination of the G3 molecules to a single Li+ cation.

elements.content: Taken together, the glyme-LiTDI phase behavior suggests that the TDI– anion has an intermediate coordinating tendency to Li+ cations (comparable to ClO4 – or BF4 –) (Table ). The DCTA– anion, in contrast, has a much greater ionic association tendency (comparable to CF3SO3 – or more so). Such an analysis is not definitive or quantitative in nature, but it suggests the Li+ cations from LiTDI are more readily solvated, which explains the relatively low conductivity of LiDCTA electrolytes with aprotic solvents and the much higher values noted for LiTDI electrolytes.
elements.clean_text: Taken together, the glyme-LiTDI phase behavior suggests that the TDI- anion has an intermediate coordinating tendency to Li+ cations (comparable to ClO4 - or BF4 -) (Table ). The DCTA- anion, in contrast, has a much greater ionic association tendency (comparable to CF3SO3 - or more so). Such an analysis is not definitive or quantitative in nature, but it suggests the Li+ cations from LiTDI are more readily solvated, which explains the relatively low conductivity of LiDCTA electrolytes with aprotic solvents and the much higher values noted for LiTDI electrolytes.

elements.content:
Comparison of the First Crystalline Solvate Phases (glyme/LiX) to Form from Dilute MixturesLiBETI is LiN(SO<sub>2</sub>C<sub>2</sub>F<sub>5</sub>)<sub>2</sub> and LiTFSI is LiN(SO<sub>2</sub>CF<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub> <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref42"></xref> G1 G2 3/1 (SSIP) 2/1 (CIP) 1/1 (AGG-I) 2/1 (SSIP) 1/1 (AGG-I) LiBETI X X LiTFSI X X LiAsF6 X X LiClO4 X X LiBF4 X X LiCF3SO3 X X LiCF3CO2 X X LiDCTA X X LiTDI (X) X X

May crystallize at low temperature.

The AGG-I (AN)2:LiTDI crystalline solvate (Figure a) has been previously reported, but was also determined as part of this study (see ). This solvate consists of isolated dimers of two ion pairs with the two coplanar TDI– anions aligned parallel to one other, each coordinating two Li+ cations. Each Li+ cation has fourfold coordination to two AN molecules and two anions (one ring and one cyano nitrogen). The AGG-I (AN)2:LiTDI solvate crystallizes from dilute (AN) n -LiTDI solutions (e.g., n = 20) at room temperature, rather than forming SSIP (AN)4:LiTDI or perhaps CIP (AN)3:LiTDI phases, suggesting that this aggregate dimer structure is particularly stable.
elements.clean_text:
Other LiTDI Crystalline Solvate Structures

The AGG-I (AN)2:LiTDI crystalline solvate (Figure a) has been previously reported, but was also determined as part of this study (see ). This solvate consists of isolated dimers of two ion pairs with the two coplanar TDI- anions aligned parallel to one other, each coordinating two Li+ cations. Each Li+ cation has fourfold coordination to two AN molecules and two anions (one ring and one cyano nitrogen). The AGG-I (AN)2:LiTDI solvate crystallizes from dilute (AN) n -LiTDI solutions (e.g., n = 20) at room temperature, rather than forming SSIP (AN)4:LiTDI or perhaps CIP (AN)3:LiTDI phases, suggesting that this aggregate dimer structure is particularly stable.

elements.content: Ion coordination in the (a) AGG-I (AN)2:LiTDI, (b) AGG-II (THF)1:LiTDI, (c) AGG-II (EC)1:LiTDI, and (d) AGG-II (PC)1:LiTDI solvate crystal structures (Li-purple, O-red, N-blue, F-light green).
elements.clean_text: 5  Ion coordination in the (a) AGG-I (AN)2:LiTDI, (b) AGG-II (THF)1:LiTDI, (c) AGG-II (EC)1:LiTDI, and (d) AGG-II (PC)1:LiTDI solvate crystal structures (Li-purple, O-red, N-blue, F-light green).

elements.content: A similar TDI– anion dimer arrangement persists when larger, cyclic solvents are used (i.e., THF, EC, and PC), although the overall coordination behavior of each structure is more aggregated than for the (AN)2:LiTDI solvate (Figure b,c,d). Specifically, for the (THF)1:LiTDI and (EC)1:LiTDI solvates, one AN···Li+ cation coordination bond is replaced with a TDI–···Li+ cation coordination bond in an adjacent dimer pair. Each dimer is thus linked to two neighboring parallel (although not coplanar) dimers on opposite sides. The resulting structures are AGG-II solvates consisting of nearly flat, polymeric chains of the dimer arrangement with the solvent molecules above and below the plane of the TDI– anions (see Figure S2). The THF and EC molecules share similar positions in the (THF)1:LiTDI and (EC)1:LiTDI solvate structures, but the EC molecules are rotated slightly closer to the plane of the anion to accommodate its larger size. Similarly, the PC molecules in the (PC)1:LiTDI solvate are rotated still closer to the plane of the TDI– anions to include the additional length of the PC methyl group. This rotation, however, significantly changes the angle of the TDI–···Li+ cation coordination bond relative to the plane of the dimer with the result that each dimer pair is coordinated to four neighboring dimers rather than two. This AGG-II solvate thus contains jagged polymeric sheets, with the PC molecules above and below the sheets, rather than polymeric chains (see ). The inclusion of the base dimer units in each of these three polymeric crystalline solvate structures again suggests that the [TDI–···Li+]2 dimer arrangement easily forms and can accommodate a variety of solvent molecules.
elements.clean_text: A similar TDI- anion dimer arrangement persists when larger, cyclic solvents are used (i.e., THF, EC, and PC), although the overall coordination behavior of each structure is more aggregated than for the (AN)2:LiTDI solvate (Figure b,c,d). Specifically, for the (THF)1:LiTDI and (EC)1:LiTDI solvates, one AN⋅⋅⋅Li+ cation coordination bond is replaced with a TDI-⋅⋅⋅Li+ cation coordination bond in an adjacent dimer pair. Each dimer is thus linked to two neighboring parallel (although not coplanar) dimers on opposite sides. The resulting structures are AGG-II solvates consisting of nearly flat, polymeric chains of the dimer arrangement with the solvent molecules above and below the plane of the TDI- anions (see  Figure S2). The THF and EC molecules share similar positions in the (THF)1:LiTDI and (EC)1:LiTDI solvate structures, but the EC molecules are rotated slightly closer to the plane of the anion to accommodate its larger size. Similarly, the PC molecules in the (PC)1:LiTDI solvate are rotated still closer to the plane of the TDI- anions to include the additional length of the PC methyl group. This rotation, however, significantly changes the angle of the TDI-⋅⋅⋅Li+ cation coordination bond relative to the plane of the dimer with the result that each dimer pair is coordinated to four neighboring dimers rather than two. This AGG-II solvate thus contains jagged polymeric sheets, with the PC molecules above and below the sheets, rather than polymeric chains (see ). The inclusion of the base dimer units in each of these three polymeric crystalline solvate structures again suggests that the [TDI-⋅⋅⋅Li+]2 dimer arrangement easily forms and can accommodate a variety of solvent molecules.

elements.content: In the AGG-III (DMC)1/2:LiTDI crystalline solvate, all four of the TDI– anion nitrogen atoms are coordinated to Li+ cations (Figure ). In contrast to the solvent molecules in the previously noted solvate structures which coordinate a single Li+ cation, each DMC molecule is coordinated to two Li+ cations. Additionally, instead of the base dimer structure of two oppositely aligned TDI– anions, an infinite three-dimensional network is formed. Two Li+ cations are coordinated by the TDI– anion ring and cyano nitrogen atoms, as in the dimer structure, but the two anions are nearly orthogonal to each other instead of sharing a plane. Since each anion is coordinated to four Li+ cations through all of the nitrogen atoms, a stairstep structure forms. In each “step”, two anions are aligned and share coordination to two Li+ cations through the two nitrile nitrogen atoms of each anion. The Li+ cations have fivefold coordination by one oxygen atom from the DMC molecules and four nitrogen atoms from four different TDI– anions.
elements.clean_text: In the AGG-III (DMC)1/2:LiTDI crystalline solvate, all four of the TDI- anion nitrogen atoms are coordinated to Li+ cations (Figure ). In contrast to the solvent molecules in the previously noted solvate structures which coordinate a single Li+ cation, each DMC molecule is coordinated to two Li+ cations. Additionally, instead of the base dimer structure of two oppositely aligned TDI- anions, an infinite three-dimensional network is formed. Two Li+ cations are coordinated by the TDI- anion ring and cyano nitrogen atoms, as in the dimer structure, but the two anions are nearly orthogonal to each other instead of sharing a plane. Since each anion is coordinated to four Li+ cations through all of the nitrogen atoms, a stairstep structure forms. In each "step", two anions are aligned and share coordination to two Li+ cations through the two nitrile nitrogen atoms of each anion. The Li+ cations have fivefold coordination by one oxygen atom from the DMC molecules and four nitrogen atoms from four different TDI- anions.

elements.content: Ion coordination in the AGG-III (DMC)1/2:LiTDI crystalline solvate structure. Solvent disorder in the DMC position has been omitted for clarity (see Supporting Information) (Li-purple, O-red, N-blue, F-light green).
elements.clean_text: 6  Ion coordination in the AGG-III (DMC)1/2:LiTDI crystalline solvate structure. Solvent disorder in the DMC position has been omitted for clarity (see Supporting Information) (Li-purple, O-red, N-blue, F-light green).

elements.content: The reported HTDI and seven new LiTDI solvate structures demonstrate a disparate range of coordination modes with the TDI– anions either uncoordinated or coordinated to one to four Li+ cations through the ring and cyano nitrogen atoms. The ring nitrogen atoms appear to have the greatest Lewis basicity, since no solvates were identified with H+ or Li+ cation coordination through only the cyano nitrogen atoms. This may, however, also be related to differences in the energetics for the favorable packing of the ions and solvent molecules in the solid state. Additionally, no Li+ cation coordination was found through the fluorine atoms. A [TDI–···Li+]2 ionic dimer arrangement appears to be prevalent in the aggregated solvates that were identified, but it is not yet clear if this type of coordination persists in the liquid phase for electrolyte solutions with aprotic solvents.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The reported HTDI and seven new LiTDI solvate structures demonstrate a disparate range of coordination modes with the TDI- anions either uncoordinated or coordinated to one to four Li+ cations through the ring and cyano nitrogen atoms. The ring nitrogen atoms appear to have the greatest Lewis basicity, since no solvates were identified with H+ or Li+ cation coordination through only the cyano nitrogen atoms. This may, however, also be related to differences in the energetics for the favorable packing of the ions and solvent molecules in the solid state. Additionally, no Li+ cation coordination was found through the fluorine atoms. A [TDI-⋅⋅⋅Li+]2 ionic dimer arrangement appears to be prevalent in the aggregated solvates that were identified, but it is not yet clear if this type of coordination persists in the liquid phase for electrolyte solutions with aprotic solvents.

elements.content: The replacement of a ring nitrogen atom in the DCTA– anion with a C–CF3 group to form the TDI– anion significantly reduces the Li+ cation ionic association tendency of the anion (thus resulting in more extensively solvated Li+ cations). This is evident from the LiDCTA and LiTDI glyme solvates formed, which indicate that the DCTA– anion has an ionic association tendency somewhat similar to CF3SO3 –, while TDI– is comparable to ClO4 – or BF4 –. These results explain why LiTDI electrolytes have distinctly higher conductivity values than comparable LiDCTA electrolytes.
elements.clean_text: The replacement of a ring nitrogen atom in the DCTA- anion with a C-CF3 group to form the TDI- anion significantly reduces the Li+ cation ionic association tendency of the anion (thus resulting in more extensively solvated Li+ cations). This is evident from the LiDCTA and LiTDI glyme solvates formed, which indicate that the DCTA- anion has an ionic association tendency somewhat similar to CF3SO3 -, while TDI- is comparable to ClO4 - or BF4 -. These results explain why LiTDI electrolytes have distinctly higher conductivity values than comparable LiDCTA electrolytes.

References

cln_elements.content: LiTDI was first reported by Bukowska et al. in 2004. Only a few publications are, as yet, available exploring the properties of this salt. In contrast with many other lithium salts (e.g., LiPF6), LiTDI is stable in water. In terms of electrolyte properties, 1 M LiTDI in ethylene carbonate/dimethyl carbonate (EC/DMC 50/50 w/w) has a conductivity of 6.7 mS cm–1 at 20 °C (the value for the corresponding LiPF6 electrolyte is 10.8 mS cm–1) and cycles well in Li|LiMn2O4 cells (comparable to cells with a similar electrolyte with LiPF6 up to a 2C rate). In addition, this LiTDI electrolyte is electrochemically stable with an Al electrode up to 4.8 V. Thus, LiTDI, in contrast with the structurally similar LiDCTA salt, holds promise as a practical electrolyte salt for batteries with high-voltage cathode materials.
cln_elements.clean_text: LiTDI was first reported by Bukowska et al. in 2004. Only a few publications are, as yet, available exploring the properties of this salt. In contrast with many other lithium salts (e.g., LiPF6), LiTDI is stable in water. In terms of electrolyte properties, 1 M LiTDI in ethylene carbonate/dimethyl carbonate (EC/DMC 50/50 w/w) has a conductivity of 6.7 mS cm-1 at 20 °C (the value for the corresponding LiPF6 electrolyte is 10.8 mS cm-1) and cycles well in Li|LiMn2O4 cells (comparable to cells with a similar electrolyte with LiPF6 up to a 2C rate). In addition, this LiTDI electrolyte is electrochemically stable with an Al electrode up to 4.8 V. Thus, LiTDI, in contrast with the structurally similar LiDCTA salt, holds promise as a practical electrolyte salt for batteries with high-voltage cathode materials.

etc.condition: 1 M LiTDI in ethylene carbonate/dimethyl carbonate (EC/DMC 50/50 w/w) at 20 °C

cln_elements.clean_text: 5  Ion coordination in the (a) AGG-I (AN)2:LiTDI, (b) AGG-II (THF)1:LiTDI, (c) AGG-II (EC)1:LiTDI, and (d) AGG-II (PC)1:LiTDI solvate crystal structures (Li-purple, O-red, N-blue, F-light green).

cln_elements.content: Ion coordination in the AGG-III (DMC)1/2:LiTDI crystalline solvate structure. Solvent disorder in the DMC position has been omitted for clarity (see Supporting Information) (Li-purple, O-red, N-blue, F-light green).
cln_elements.clean_text: 6  Ion coordination in the AGG-III (DMC)1/2:LiTDI crystalline solvate structure. Solvent disorder in the DMC position has been omitted for clarity (see Supporting Information) (Li-purple, O-red, N-blue, F-light green).

metadata.title:
Anion Coordination
Interactions in Solvates with the Lithium Salts LiDCTA and LiTDI
